articles.headline: Dogs Test Drug Aimed at Humans’ Biggest Killer: Age
articles.snippet: A drug that lengthened the lives of laboratory mice is being tested on dogs as scientists look for alternatives to treating one disease at a time.
articles.abstract: A drug that lengthened the lives of laboratory mice is being tested on dogs as scientists look for alternatives to treating one disease at a time.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Ever since last summer, when Lynn Gemmell’s dog, Bela, was inducted into the trial of a drug that has been shown to significantly lengthen the lives of laboratory mice, she has been the object of intense scrutiny among dog park regulars.

articles.headline: The Strange, Unending Limbo of Egypt’s Hosni Mubarak
articles.snippet: The deposed leader remains confined to a hospital room in Cairo even as many former allies cut deals with the government to overturn their own convictions.
articles.abstract: The deposed leader remains confined to a hospital room in Cairo even as many former allies cut deals with the government to overturn their own convictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — In many ways, life is not so bad for Egypt’s deposed ruler, Hosni Mubarak. At the Cairo hospital he calls home, he enjoys regular deliveries of flowers, newspapers and takeout restaurant meals; visits from his wife, two sons and grandchildren; and a sweeping view over the Nile.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and Nour Youssef

articles.headline: TV’s Big Bet on Nostalgia
articles.snippet: In the upcoming season, networks are offering new versions of shows like “MacGyver,” “Prison Break” and “MTV Unplugged.”
articles.abstract: In the upcoming season, networks are offering new versions of shows like “MacGyver,” “Prison Break” and “MTV Unplugged.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The television industry is facing an uncertain, uncharted future. But next season it’s placing a big bet on the past.

articles.headline: Rift Between Labor and Environmentalists Threatens Democratic Turnout Plan
articles.snippet: A group of construction unions threatened to boycott a big new Democratic get-out-the-vote operation this fall unless a wealthy opponent of climate change is barred from it.
articles.abstract: A group of construction unions threatened to boycott a big new Democratic get-out-the-vote operation this fall unless a wealthy opponent of climate change is barred from it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two of the Democratic Party’s most loyal constituencies, labor and environmentalists, are clashing over an effort to raise tens of millions of dollars for an ambitious voter turnout operation aimed at defeating Donald J. Trump in the November election.

articles.headline: China Quietly Targets U.S. Tech Companies in Security Reviews
articles.snippet: A committee with ties to the country’s military and security agencies is requiring foreign tech giants like Apple to answer questions about encryption and data storage.
articles.abstract: A committee with ties to the country’s military and security agencies is requiring foreign tech giants like Apple to answer questions about encryption and data storage.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Chinese authorities are quietly scrutinizing technology products sold in China by Apple and other big foreign companies, focusing on whether they pose potential security threats to the country and its consumers and opening up a new front in an already tense relationship with Washington over digital security.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Stuck With a Pricey Hotel Reservation? Maybe You Can Sell It
articles.snippet: As travel cancellation restrictions and fees become more widespread, travelers are listing nonrefundable hotel reservations on resale sites.
articles.abstract: As travel cancellation restrictions and fees become more widespread, travelers are listing nonrefundable hotel reservations on resale sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: In March, Alysa Turner, a publicist from Washington, booked a hotel room through Southwest Airlines’ rewards program. She paid $400 for a one-night stay at the Hilton San Francisco Union Square, but her plans changed after the window for canceling the reservation had closed.

articles.headline: Election Years Are Steeped in Markets’ Least Favorite Thing: Uncertainty
articles.snippet: Research shows that presidential election years paralyze businesses that fear making their next moves with the future so uncertain.
articles.abstract: Research shows that presidential election years paralyze businesses that fear making their next moves with the future so uncertain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mergers and acquisitions activity is down. Initial public offerings are practically dead. Companies are cutting spending. The stock market is increasingly volatile. Gross domestic product is stalling.

articles.headline: Want to Buy a Self-Driving Car? Big-Rig Trucks May Come First
articles.snippet: A start-up has its sights on the long-haul freeway driving that is the bread and butter of the commercial trucking industry.
articles.abstract: A start-up has its sights on the long-haul freeway driving that is the bread and butter of the commercial trucking industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Imagine you are driving on a highway late at night when a big-rig truck closes in behind you. You relax because it is keeping a safe distance and seems to be obeying the speed limit. Now imagine that truck is driving itself.

articles.headline: Hiring Hurdle: Finding Workers Who Can Pass a Drug Test
articles.snippet: As labor markets tighten, employers are having a harder time finding applicants free of drugs, especially marijuana.
articles.abstract: As labor markets tighten, employers are having a harder time finding applicants free of drugs, especially marijuana.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAVANNAH, Ga. — A few years back, the heavy-equipment manufacturer  JCB held a job fair in the glass foyer of its sprawling headquarters near here, but when a throng of prospective employees learned the next step would be drug testing, an alarming thing happened: About half of them left.

articles.headline: Yes, ISIS Is Losing in Iraq. No, It’s Not in Its Death Throes.
articles.snippet: Four bombings in predominantly Shiite neighborhoods across Baghdad left 80 dead and many more wounded.
articles.abstract: Four bombings in predominantly Shiite neighborhoods across Baghdad left 80 dead and many more wounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: Another day brought another horrible set of headlines out of Baghdad: On Tuesday, four bombings, one after another, killed dozens of people and left streaks of blood and strewn body parts across public markets.
